MALAYANISATION OF CITY COUNCIL POSTS


    1. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Prime Minister (a) how many expatriates are still holding posts in the City Council; (b) when these posts will eventually be Malayanised: and (c) whether experienced local officers are receiving training locally or abroad to prepare them for taking over from the expatriates.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, at the moment there are 10 expatriate officers in the Departments of the City Council which have been integrated with the Departments of the Government. Two of the expatriate officers are on the permanent service, having been offered guaranteed employment by the former City Council under its Malayanisation scheme, one up to 1964 and the other up to 1966. Eight expatriate officers are on contracts, of which four will expire during the course of this year: two in 1963 and one in 1964. One expatriate officer is on a month-to-month basis.

    Local officers in City Council Departments which have been integrated with the Government are receiving training locally and overseas or have been earmarked for further training and will replace expatriate officers as planned for in Government service. There are 27 expatriate officers now holding posts in the City Council Departments that will form the Public Utilities Board. Twelve of these officers were offered guaranteed employment by the former City Council under its Malayanisation scheme as follows:-

MALAYANISATION OF GOVERNMENT POSTS


    2. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance (a) how many expatriates are still holding posts in the Government; (b) when these posts will eventually be Malayanised: and (c) whether experienced local officers are receiving training locally or abroad to prepare them for taking over from the expatriates.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: There were 509 permanent expatriate officers in the Government service before Malayanisation. Today there are only 13 permanent expatriate officers still in the service. Therefore, Malayanisation has been proceeding faster than scheduled.

    According to the Malayanisation programme, there should still be 113 permanent expatriate officers in the service. There are, in addition to the 13 permanent expatriate officers, 54 expatriate officers on short-term contracts in the Government. Of these, 47 are either technical or professional officers whose services are required because of the

Column: 319

shortage of local professional and technical officers. Suitable local officers are receiving training locally or abroad to prepare them for taking over from the expatriates. We now have no less than 105 persons studying abroad on training courses at Universities and professional institutes.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether those local officers who are sent abroad for training are chosen because of experience in their work or seniority, or is it because they are new people just receiving training.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The persons sent abroad for training can be conveniently grouped into three grades. First, there are serving officers who are sent abroad on short-term training courses; for instance, the staff of Civil Aviation who were sent either to Australia or New Zealand to take specialist courses in Airport Management, in radar control, and so on, and when they come back they will be more efficient after having undergone these training courses.

    Then there are specialist professional courses which we offer to serving officers in certain senior technical grades. Most of these really are courses leading to post-graduate or specialist qualifications which are offered to doctors, and a fair number of doctors are studying in the United Kingdom and Australia.

    Then there are first professional training courses or first degree courses which we offer to young persons. Under the previous Government, recruitment for such training courses has been from serving officers in the junior grades; for instance, P.W.D. architectural or engineering technicians or Telecommunications technicians have been given the opportunity to take full professional courses, say, in England.

    We have found that this policy is wasteful because quite often these junior technical officers have not either the intellectual capacity or the academic background to benefit from these courses. They either just scrape through with a very low pass degree or, as happens only too often, they fail in their professional or academic examinations.

Column: 320

So for such courses - for instance, we are having any number of persons doing professional degrees in Engineering or Science or Quantity Surveying etc. - we are getting them straight from those who have passed the Higher School Certificate Examination, and each year we are getting some of the best of these persons for these higher professional training courses.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, is it true to say then that at the top where there are senior officers serving under the expatriates, the senior officer is being trained to take over the expatriate's job, apart from the junior officers?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I think the question may give the impression that expatriate officers are always above the local senior officers. In fact, all the top posts, i.e, the highest posts in the civil service, like the post of Permanent Secretary, have already been Malayanised, and the expatriates do not occupy them. Take the P.W.D., for instance. The Director of Public Works and his Deputy are local officers. That is the case too in the Ministry of Health. But we need bodies - that is the main thing. You have to have a doctor, or a surgeon, or an engineer. Because we ate so short of these persons. and if they are expatriates and willing to work here. I would say it is all for the good if we can get an extra body to carry the load.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry I did not make it clear to the Minister. I did lot mean that the expatriate is always at the top. What I meant is that if a serving expatriate is to be Malayanised, is the local officer immediately beneath him, irrespective of whatever post he holds, being trained to take over his post?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I would say that is the general position. But, of course, there are exceptions. For instance, in the Deputy Prime Minister's portfolio there are Departments such as the Marine Survey Department where you just do not have any local officer, or very few of them, with the requisite professional

Column: 321

qualifications. But apart from such rather exclusive services, the position is that local people are being trained to take over.

HARI RAYA PUASA


    3. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he would consider giving two days' holiday to Muslims for Hari Raya Puasa when Hari Raya Puasa falls on the day after the gazetted holiday.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, on occasions when Han Raya Puasa falls on the day after the gazetted holiday, the practice has been, after consultation with the Muslim Advisory Board, not to declare an additional holiday, but for the Government to give Muslim Government servants time off in the morning to perform their prayers. INDUSTRIAL UNREST


2.46 p.m.

    Order read for resumption of proceedings on Amendment [16th March, 1962] to Question [16th March, 1962],

    "That this House views with grave concern the mounting of industrial unrest and calls on the Government to take all reasonable steps to ensure industrial peace with justice in the interests of the economic well-being of the people of Singapore.". - (Tun Lim Yew Hock).

Column: 323



    Which Amendment was,

    `To leave out "views with grave concern the mounting of industrial unrest" in lines 1 and 2 and insert "takes note of the public manifestations of industrial dissatisfaction".' - (Mr David Marshall).

    Question proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Mr Speaker: The debate now must be confined to the amendment. Any Member wishing to speak on the amendment?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: On the amendment?

    Mr Speaker: Only on the amendment.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I cannot accept the amendment proposed by the Member for Anson. It is my submission that this House views with grave concern the mounting of industrial unrest, have quoted facts and figures to show beyond any doubt that there has been mounting industrial unrest, and surely, Sir, as representatives of the people, we cannot but view this with grave concern, because such a situation is detrimental to the economic well-being of the people of Singapore.

    Sir, let us now examine the amendment proposed by the Member for Anson. He does not view the mounting industrial unrest with grave concern. By his amendment, he wants this House not to view the mounting industrial unrest with grave concern. Strange, Sir. But is it really strange, especially as this comes from the Member for Anson? in his short speech last Friday, he made reference to the time when I was Minister for Labour and Welfare when he was Chief Minister. When he took office, there was too a spate of strikes, some of which were of a political character. He did not view this with alarm. He did not view this with grave concern, in fact, when he was surrounded by the Press, who were anxious to hear from him what plans he had to meet this challenge, he said with a broad smile. "I love strikes." He loves strikes, Sir. indeed, it might be that it is because of his love for strikes that the Hock Lee strike in 1955 culminated in a bloody riot and the then Chief Minister became

Column: 324

a sick man. One would have thought, Sir, that he would have learned something from his bitter experience. But it would seem from his manifestations last Friday in this House that he is incurable, in so far as this particular economic ill is concerned. He wants this House to take note. Take note! Surely hon. Members of this House, as well as the public, have been taking note for some months past of the mounting industrial unrest. And we, having taken note of the mounting industrial unrest now feel grave concern for such a situation as it has created havoc in the economic field in Singapore. There may be some hon. Members who may not view this mounting industrial unrest with grave concern, but if there are such Members, they have failed in their sacred duty to look after the economic well-being of the people who elected them.

    Sir, what does the Member for Anson want us to take note? He wants us to take note of the public manifestations of industrial dissatisfaction. I say there has been mounting industrial unrest and there are facts and figures to bear me out. This simple statement of absolute truth appears to have stung the Member for Anson into attempting to interpret the present lamentable situation as a public manifestation of industrial dissatisfaction. High sounding words indeed, Sir. Behind them is implied the attitude of the Member for Anson. By his own words, he takes the stand that all the strikes that have bedevilled the country are just, and that trade unions should be given free rein to do damage to the economy of the country and thus to do damage to their own members. I have not in my speech condemned the trade unions for the industrial unrest. What I have sought to do in my motion is to call on the Government to do everything possible to bring about industrial peace with justice, because without industrial peace the economic well-being of the people of Singapore will be jeopardised. A sober speech of mine seems to have made the Member for Anson see in it a touch of hysteria. Sir, it is only one who has been on the fringe of hysteria who can see hysteria

Column: 325

where there is no hysteria. This is a sort of illness which one would call a hallucination.

    Sir, the Member for Anson says that lie has put in his amendment with a view to restoring a sense of balance into the industrial picture. A sense of balance indeed! The hon. Member wants us to accept something that is not borne out by facts in place of something that has been borne out by facts. And he calls this as "restoring a sense of balance". Sir, I cannot accept this because I refuse to allow my mind to be unbalanced by this senseless sense of balance.

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): He is gila!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the hon. Member for Anson in his short speech took it upon himself to ridicule me when I made mention of the strike at the Oversea-Chinese Bank in relation to Part VII of the Industrial Relations Ordinance. When I heard him raise the objection. I listened more attentively to his speech and tried to find out from him the reasons for his objection. I heard nothing at all, Sir. This would make me feel that the hon. Member was speaking through ignorance. For his benefit - although he is not here at the moment - and for the benefit of Members who may share the same view as the Member for Anson, let me explain in greater detail what Part VII of the Industrial Relations Ordinance is meant to do.

    Mr Speaker: Order, Is this part of the hon. Member's speech in relation to the amendment? If it is not, then he will have the opportunity of answering that argument at the end of the debate when he replies to the whole motion.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I feel that it will be better if I reserve this. I brought it in just now because it was referred to in the speech of the Member for Anson. I think he brought that up in order to explain away his sense of a touch of hysteria in my very sober speech. I would prefer, Sir, if I may to leave this till the main motion.

Column: 326



    Mr Speaker: Any Member who wishes to speak on the amendment? If not, I will put the Question on the amendment.

The original Question was.

    "That this House views with grave concern the mounting of industrial unrest and calls on the Government to take all reasonable steps to ensure industrial peace with justice in the interests of the economic well-being of the people of Singapore."

    Since which an amendment has been moved,

    To leave out "views with grave concern the mounting of industrial unrest" in lines 1 and 2 and there to insert "takes note of the public manifestations of industrial dissatisfaction".

    Question, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out," put, and negatived.

    Mr Speaker: The amendment falls. We are now back to the original motion.

    Question again proposed.

3.01 p.m.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am surprised that a subject of such importance should not evoke a greater response from the other Parties. Perhaps that shows that all the Parties represented in the House are agreed that the state of industrial unrest in Singapore is such that it causes grave concern to all who are interested in the welfare of the people of Singapore.

    Sir, there was a time when the general public would read a report of some industrial trouble with a smile, with passing interest, and make it a subject of conversation at tea parties and so on. Today we are all conscious that when we view this problem, we view it against a sombre background of an ever increasing number of unemployed. The problem is not merely a question of getting fair wages and increasing wages, of which we are all in favour, hut it is a question of encouraging more industries and encouraging traders to expand and employ more people, so that this grave social problem of unemployment can be solved. It is quite frequent coming across a family of five or six depending just on one member. I was visiting some families in an attap house area and I

Column: 327

came across a family with about five able-bodied young men, and a widowed mother. Of these five, only one was employed. This one had taken his Senior Cambridge examination and, after a year of unemployment, had at last got a job as a watchman at $4.75 a day. When he looked at me wondering what my opinion was, I said, "You are very lucky to be employed. Never mind false pride. Take it on for the sake of your family." I asked the young men around him. One said, "I too applied for the post of watchman, but there were so many applying that I could not get the job." What about the others, who were not highly educated? They would not be able to get jobs even as casual labourers.

    There is a case of another man, who had a good job and then was retrenched. He has a large family. After a desperate search for a job, he gave up and his young son who had just left school managed to get a job as an apprentice at a salary of slightly over $100 a month. The whole family, about five or six of them, are dependent on this particular youngster. Naturally, he cannot make ends meet. Meanwhile, the schools are producing thousands of youngsters. Youngsters are leaving the schools by the thousands looking for jobs, and instead of finding more jobs in Singapore, they find a situation where jobs are decreasing in number.

    Sir, we have read out statistics to prove that since 1957 there are probably something like 15,000 to 17,000 jobs less than before. It is against this background that you have to study this problem of industrial unrest. Yesterday in the Sunday Mail, Sir, we had almost a full-page article entitled "In Search of a Job". The article describes how the writer in 1945 found he could choose any of four jobs. Today there is just a scramble. There are the job-seekers, but there are no jobs.

    Sir, the Minister for Finance was optimistic that his industrial plans could be effected and he went to Japan optimistically trying to attract Japanese capitalists. When he came back, he admitted that the Japanese investors were worried because of the possibility of more labour troubles when they had

Column: 328

invested their capital in Singapore enterprises. The question now is this: who are responsible for these labour troubles? Some people say the Communists are responsible. When I spoke to some of these workers, they admitted that, viewed selfishly, they liked these labour troubles because at the end of every strike they gained higher wages. One cannot but view sympathetically when we look at the problems simply from that angle. But they have to see that if by getting an increase they thereby penalise their unemployed sons and daughters, that price may be too high. I suggest that, instead of viewing this problem from two sides - we usually talk about two sides to a question - we should view it this time from four sides. There is the viewpoint of the workers. We are all very much in favour of giving them higher and higher wages. The Government has a grouse against me in particular because I have kept on digging at them because of the pay-cuts. We are all in favour, if the Government earns more, it gets more revenue, and we want better treatment for the employees. In the same way, if the employers earn more and make more profits, we want higher wages for their workers.

    We look at it from the point of view of the merchants, the investors, the capitalists. If they dump money into Singapore, they expect returns. Just two weeks ago, a man was telling me that he was building a factory. I asked him, "Where?" "Not in Singapore," he said. Where? Johore Bahru. That means more employment for the people across the causeway and not enough employment, for us here. Naturally, the investors look at it from the angle of profits themselves.

    But look at it from the point of view of the unemployed. I sometimes wonder whether they should not be allowed to organise themselves into another trade union in this situation where in their own interests, if industrial unrest reaches a high proportion, they could demand that the Government should step in and compel every dispute to be submitted to arbitration. Perhaps when we look at it in that light from the point of view of the unemployed, we see reason, we can

Column: 329

see that there is need for another approach to this problem, not merely for ourselves, but of service to the unemployed.

    Now, what about the other people the general public? The general public suffer inconvenience. The general public are made up of not only people who are unemployed, but they are also made up of the wives and children of the strikers. I remember talking to one trade union leader who led a strike in the Singapore Traction Company for over five months and the Communists supplied him with money to enable him to go on with the strike. But he said a year after that when he had seen the sufferings of the wives of the strikers and their children, he decided that thereafter if he could find a way of solving a deadlock without a strike, he would do it. The strike would be the last weapon and the last resort, because innocent people would be made to suffer. I hope, Sir, that we look at this problem of industrial unrest therefore not merely from the view point of the workers and the businessmen, but also from the point of view of the unemployed in particular.

    Some people say it is natural that in a strike there is a clash of interests. Any political Party must be on the side of the workers, it is agreed. But let us look at it from another angle, using another approach. Why should the interests of the workers and the employers clash? Are not these two like the wings of a bird? If we damage one wing, what happens to the bird? It cannot fly any more. if we can look at it in that way, that workers and employers both play important parts, that both are like the wings of a bird, and if both are equally strong and cooperating, the bird can fly to greater heights and Singapore can reap greater prosperity, and this prosperity can be shared among more people. The unemployed will have a chance in life and the young people coming out from schools will have a future they can look forward to. If we can look at it from that point of view, Sir, then we can have a hope of solving this problem of industrial unrest. But if we look at it

Column: 330

from the point of view of a political struggle, if one Party must outbid the other Party, then, Sir, God help the unemployed.

3.12 p.m.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, industrial unrest is not peculiar to Singapore. It is a feature of industrialised or industrialising societies all over the world, in England today, the Government is faced with balance of payments difficulties, and to offset inflationary pressures for general wage increases, has refused civil service claims for improvements in pay and conditions, with the result that teachers, local government employees technical staff, postal clerks and civil service clerks, who are the traditional moderates of the trade union movement in England, have been forced into the front line of the industrial battle.

    A strike can arise for a variety of reasons and not necessarily because of a dispute about wages and conditions of work. In the B.O.A.C. strike which took place last July, the engineering staff were up in arms against the reorganisational programme of the management with which the union disagreed, even though the management could prove that in the reorganisation, not a single worker would lose his job. The P.A.P. Government has consistently been pro-worker. The first thing we did as a Government was to amend the Trade Union Ordinance to give the Registrar of Trade Unions the power to cancel the registration of trade unions who were splinter or yellow unions and to refuse registration to dissident groups who sought to set up breakaway unions. This prevented the manipulation of the trade union movement by unscrupulous employers.

    The next thing we did was to ensure that the labour laws were enforced. All employers were required to send in returns of their employees to the Ministry and whenever a report reached the Ministry that the labour laws were not being observed, an inspector was sent round to make an on-the-spot enquiry. If the enquiry disclosed that an employer was not observing the labour laws, immediate action was taken to compel

Column: 331

compliance. The Labour Court was strengthened and employees who were wrongfully dismissed or who were denied the benefits of the labour legislation were given every facility to claim payments in lieu of arrears of overtime pay and annual leave which had been denied to them. A sum of more than $1½ million was recovered from employers for the benefit of their employees in this way.

    To assist the unions, legislation was enacted to make it obligatory for all collective agreements to be registered with the Industrial Arbitration Court and every registered collective agreement is published in the Government Gazette. Where the parties fail to reach agreement, the Industrial Arbitration Court, which is constituted by an independent Chairman and two members, each of whom is drawn from a panel of employers and union nominees, is empowered to take evidence from the disputing parties and to make an award. Both the award and the registered agreement are legally enforceable by the Court. The Court has the power in trade disputes to fix wages, salaries, allowances and other remuneration by prescribing time rates, piece work rates, salary scales, bonus payments, severance pay, retirement benefits, or to make other prescriptions which it considers to be appropriate.

    In addition, the same legislation provides ample machinery for conciliation when a trade dispute is threatened or arises and recourse to arbitration can be had by a joint request by the contending parties or by a reference of the dispute to the Court by the Minister and, in the case of the Government service or the essential services, by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara.

    For the period 15th September, 1960 to 31st December, 1960, eight awards were made by the Industrial Arbitration Court in industrial disputes and a total of 121 collective agreements covering a total of 36,269 employees were certified and registered by the Court. Up to date, there are eight cases pending before the Court, two of which are considered to be major disputes.

Column: 332



    This indicates that the machinery for conciliation and settlement of industrial disputes is being used by the bona fide union leaders in the non-Communist unions. But these facts by themselves do not give us a true picture of what is happening in the trade union field.

    There were 45 strikes and lockouts in 1960 involving 5,939 workers and 152,005 man-days were lost.

    The split in the trade union movement between unions affiliated to the S.A.T.U group of Communist-controlled trade unions and unions not so aligned took place in July last year. From the 1st July, 1961, to the 31st January, 1962, there were altogether 96 strikes as compared to 27 only for the first six months of 1961. Of the 96 strikes, 69 were called by the unions affiliated to the S.A.TU. group, 24 by unions not so aligned and three by employees not presented by any union. Of the 69 strikes called by the S.A.T.U. group of trade unions, 25 strikes involved expatriate firms whereas only six of the 24 strikes called by unions not aligned to the S.A.T.U. group involved expatriate employers.

    Twenty of the 31 strikes against expatriate employers were called by the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union, two by the Singapore Motor Workshop Employees' Union and one each by the Singapore General Employees' Union, the Singapore Spinning Workers' Union and the Singapore Shoe Employees' Union.
